author: Kate Chopin
name: Désirée's Baby
description: It is about miscegenation in Creole Louisiana during the antebellum period.

author: Kate Chopin
name: The Story of an Hour
description: The title of the short story refers to the time elapsed between the moments at which the protagonist, Louise Mallard, hears that her husband, Brently Mallard, is dead, then discovers that he is alive after all. Featuring a female protagonist who feels liberation at the news of her husband's death, "The Story of an Hour" was controversial by American standards in the 1890s.

author: Kate Chopin
name: The Storm
description: This story is the sequel to Chopin's "At the 'Cadian Ball."

author: Kate Chopin
name: The Awakening
description: Set in New Orleans and on the Louisiana Gulf coast at the end of the 19th century, the plot centers on Edna Pontellier and her struggle between her increasingly unorthodox views on femininity and motherhood with the prevailing social attitudes of the turn-of-the-century American South. It is one of the earliest American novels that focuses on women's issues without condescension. It is also widely seen as a landmark work of early feminism, generating a mixed reaction from contemporary readers and critics.

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
name: The Beautiful and Damned
description: It explores and portrays New York café society and the American Eastern elite during the Jazz Age before and after the Great War in the early 1920s. As in his other novels, Fitzgerald's characters in this novel are complex, materialistic and experience significant disruptions in respect to classism, marriage, and intimacy. The work generally is considered to be based on Fitzgerald's relationship and marriage with his wife Zelda Fitzgerald.

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
name: Winter Dreams
description: The plot concerns the attempts by a young man to win the affections of an upper-class woman. The story, frequently anthologized, is regarded as one of Fitzgerald's finest works "for poignantly portraying the loss of youthful illusions."

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
name: Babylon Revisited
description: The story is set in the year after the stock market crash of 1929, just after what Fitzgerald called the Jazz Age. Brief flashbacks take place in the Jazz Age. Also it shows several references to the Great Depression and how the character had to adapt his life to it. Much of it is based on the author's own experiences.

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Lost Lover
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Sorrowful Guest
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Late Supper
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Mr. Bruce
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Miss Sydney’s Flowers
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Lady Ferry
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Bit of Shore Life
description: Old Friends and New

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: The Country of the Pointed Firs

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Country Doctor
description: The main character of A Country Doctor, Nan, is a young woman that encounters much strife when she decides to go against the traditional values of the day and become a doctor.

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A White Heron
description: It follows a young city girl named Sylvia who came to live with her grandmother in the country. She meets a young ornithologist hunter seeking to find a rare bird that he recently spotted in the area. As the story progresses, Sylvia is challenged with whether or not she should tell the hunter she saw the bird. She also discovers her passion for country life and her love and values for the animals that inhabit it.

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: The Life of Nancy
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Fame’s Little Day
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A War Debt
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: The Hiltons Holiday
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: The Only Rose
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Second Spring
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Little French Mary
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: The Guests of Mrs. Timms
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: Neighbor’s Landmark
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: My Sad Captains
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Sarah Orne Jewett
name: A Winter Courtship
description: The Life of Nancy

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The House Behind the Cedars
description: he story occurs in the southern American states of North and South Carolina a few years following the American Civil War. Rena Walden, a young woman of mixed white and black ancestry, leaves home to join her brother, who has migrated to a new city, where he lives as a white man. Following her brother's lead, Rena begins living as a white woman. The secret of her identity leads to conflict when she falls in love with a white aristocrat who learns the truth of her heredity. The ensuing drama emphasizes themes of interracial relations and depicted the intricacies of racial identity in the American south.

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Colonel's Dream
description: The Colonel's Dream portrays the continuing oppression and racial violence prominent in the Southern United States after the American Civil War. The Colonel's Dream concerns Colonel Henry French and his attempt to refine Clarendon, North Carolina, the southern city in which he grew up, into a racially and socially equal society from the strictly segregationist ways of its past.

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Marrow of Tradition
description: A historical novel set at the time and portraying a fictional account of the Wilmington Insurrection of 1898 in Wilmington, North Carolina.

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Goophered Grapevine
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: Po' Sandy
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: Mars Jeems's Nightmare
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Conjurer's Revenge
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: Sis' Becky's Pickaninny
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Grey Wolf's Ha'nt
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: Hot-Foot Hannibal
description: The Conjure Woman

author: Charles W. Chesnutt
name: The Wife of His Youth
description: The story has been read as an analysis of race relations, not between black and white but within the black community, exploring its own color and class prejudices. The main character dreams of becoming white but ultimately seems to accept being black and the full history of African Americans in the United States. The ending of the story, however, has been called ambiguous and leaves several questions unanswered.

author: Mary E. Wilkins Freeman
name: Pembroke
description: It is set in the small town of Pembroke, Massachusetts in the 1830s and 40s. The novel tells the story of a romance gone awry and the dramatic events that follow, which entertain the residents of the small town for years after.

author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
name: The Yellow Wallpaper
description: It is regarded as an important early work of American feminist literature for its illustration of the attitudes towards mental and physical health of women in the 19th century.

author: Henry James
name: The Wings of the Dove
description: It tells the story of Milly Theale, an American heiress stricken with a serious disease, and her effect on the people around her. Some of these people befriend Milly with honourable motives, while others are more self-interested.

author: Henry James
name: The American
description: The novel is an uneasy combination of social comedy and melodrama concerning the adventures and misadventures of Christopher Newman, an essentially good-hearted but rather gauche American businessman on his first tour of Europe. Newman is looking for a world different from the simple, harsh realities of 19th-century American business. He encounters both the beauty and the ugliness of Europe, and learns not to take either for granted. The core of the novel concerns Newman's courtship of a young widow from an aristocratic Parisian family.

author: Henry James
name: Daisy Miller
description: It portrays the courtship of the beautiful American girl Daisy Miller by Winterbourne, a sophisticated compatriot of hers. His pursuit of her is hampered by her own flirtatiousness, which is frowned upon by the other expatriates when they meet in Switzerland and Italy.

author: Henry James
name: Washington Square
description: It is a structurally simple tragicomedy that recounts the conflict between a dull but sweet daughter and her brilliant, unemotional father.

author: Henry James
name: The Altar of the Dead
description: A fable of literally life and death significance, the story explores how the protagonist tries to keep the remembrance of his dead friends, to save them from being forgotten entirely in the rush of everyday events. He meets a woman who shares his ideals, only to find that the past places what seems to be an impassable barrier between them. Although James was not religious in any conventional sense, the story shows a deep spirituality in its treatment of mortality and the transcendent power of unselfish love.

author: Henry James
name: The Beast in the Jungle
description: Almost universally considered one of James' finest short narratives, this story treats appropriately universal themes: loneliness, fate, love and death.

author: Henry James
name: The Sacred Fount
description: This strange, often baffling book concerns an unnamed narrator who attempts to discover the truth about the love lives of his fellow guests at a weekend party in the English countryside. He spurns the "detective and keyhole" methods as ignoble, and instead tries to decipher these relationships purely from the behavior and appearance of each guest. He expends huge resources of energy and ingenuity on his theories, much to the bemusement of some people at the party.

author: Henry James
name: The Golden Bowl
description: Set in England, this complex, intense study of marriage and adultery completes what some critics have called the "major phase" of James's career. The Golden Bowl explores the tangle of interrelationships between a father and daughter and their respective spouses. The novel focuses deeply and almost exclusively on the consciousness of the central characters, with sometimes obsessive detail but also with powerful insight.

author: Henry James
name: The Pupil
description: It is the emotional story of a precocious young boy growing up in a mendacious and dishonorable family. He befriends his tutor, who is the only adult in his life that he can trust. James presents their relationship with sympathy and insight, and the story reaches what some would consider the status of classical tragedy.

author: Henry James
name: In the Cage
description: This long story centers on an unnamed London telegraphist. She deciphers clues to her clients' personal lives from the often cryptic telegrams they submit to her as she sits in the "cage" at the post office. Sensitive and intelligent, the telegraphist eventually finds out more than she may want to know.

author: Ambrose Bierce
name: An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge
